content:
If you have any clean up files program running like CCleaner or WiseCleaner then you need to make the Thunderbird profile exempt from cleanup. Please note that some Anti-Virus products also provide this service, so you may need to make Thunderbird exempt from the cleanup. Those type of programs may be deleting the session.json file, so when Thunderbird starts it is using a new default session file which would not know what you had opened in last session.

Suggest you try the following just in case some files are not working as they should be. Menu icon > Help > More TRoubleshooting Information Under 'Application Basics' section - half way is Profile Folder - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

Exit Thunderbird now.

Delete the following files:

  • session.json
  • xulstore.json

Start Thunderbird.

Use for a good while, opening a few tabs and then exit Thunderbird. Wait a few moments for background processes to complete, then restart Thunderbird.

Remember, when you exit Thunderbird, wait a few moments to ensure background processes have completed before closing down computer.

content:
Perhaps the issue is your setup is not complete.

Starting with the description. As this is the human readable entry for you to confirm the correct SMTP server is used with the correct mail account. It is mandatory. Even if the machine can work without it. You can not confirm settings are correct in account settings.

Password: I understand from the plusnet web site a password is not required it is optional, if you are signed into the internet using their service. Use one anyway. You never know when you might find yourself connected via a neighbors WiFi by accident or in the case of a tablet or laptop at an internet hotspot in a train station of a cafe. That should not be the source of random email issues, but without a password it will be.

Connection security: The plusnet web site says STARTTLS your setting is none. Not going to work that way.

They even go so far as to say if your can not use STARTTLS but SSL/TLS insted to use port 465. As your provider is asking you to use STARTTLS, an encrypted connection on the port you have set. I suggest you do as they ask.

As a general rule mail settings are a lesson in copying what the provider tells you to use. Plus net have their setting published here. Where they offer this somewhat confusing bit of advice

If you've been with us a while, your domain might be '.force9.co.uk or '.free-online.net'. If so, change '.plus.net' to '.force9.net' or '.free-online.net' for both your incoming and outgoing servers.
I guess those domain names are to be determined based on the domain part of your email address as they fail to tell you how it is worked. On that assumption you email address would be ending in plus.com. Per https://www.plus.net/help/email-guides/how-to-use-plusnet-email/

An encrypted connection might give some antivirus products a fit as they can't scan your connection unless you step though a load of hoops reducing your inherent security so they can scan outgoing mail on a system they say is clean. But that is beyond the scope of this forum.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The reason you cannot send is because most of your smtp server settings are incorrect and not as advised by plusnet.

A Plusnet email address looks like this: something@username.plus.com.

SMTP server Settings:

  • Description : enter username
  • Server Name: relay.plus.net (NOT relay.plus.com)
  • Port : 587
  • Connection Security: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User Name: username part of email address
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :sent from my AOL account to my wife's Thunderbird email

You did not mention what server your wife uses. It would also be useful to know if she used a Pop or Imap account. Thunderbird is just the program she is using as the email client.

Your wife would need to logon to her webmail account via a browser. Then check to see if the email actually arrived in the account. If she uses a POP account in Thunderbird and the email did arrive in webmail account BUT the server anti-spam thought it was spam and put it in server Spam folder, then it would not get seen in her POP account in Thunderbird. Why ? Because Pop accounts can only access the server Inbox and download a copy of email from inbox to pop account Inbox.

She would need to locate mail in Spam folder and instruct server that it's not spam.

content: Each time the files are updated, the date/time changes. From your description of your backup strategy, you will end up with many copies. You might consider backing up once a day to minimize the multiple copies. This is not a Thunderbird issue, but a result of how you do backups.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks for your response. In fact, I do back up only once per day and even with this back up schedule my flash drive fills quickly. I agree it doesn't seem to be a TBird issue but I'm trying to cover all possibilities. For unknown reasons only my Gmail folders are copied each day and backed up to the flash drive as if each day's files were not connected to the previous day. This does not happen with any other folders and files so it seems there is something unique taking place. I just don't know what it might be. I thought maybe someone else also ran into this problem.
creator: neil.baron.1139

content:
I use "Backup Using File History".

That implicitly says a copy of every version of every file. When you get an email the file changes. When you delete an email it changes again. I would see that strategy potentially making dozens of copies of the files daily really.

Just to demonstrate. Open the window file explorer. Locate the file, right click it, select properties and have a look at the previous versions tab. That is what you are selecting to backup.

Personally I do not have the windows shadow copy enabled at all as it uses a very significant amounts of disk space, and in the case of my 4.5Gb inbox file basically stops the system while it is copied after every change.

I do not allow the windows indexing service to index those files in my profile folder either as yet again in slows the system. Indexing huge files that have had maybe 200 characters changed is not a good use of the speed I bought.

Drop the history strategy and the problem will go away is my take on it.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: davidsk

content:
This sounds like a DNS issue to me. Propagation of DNS changes can actually take weeks to get to all the more remote corners of the internet (read you home server in that).

I would suggest setting the DNS to something like cloudflare (over HTTPS for best results) or Google DNS servers and see if the issue goes away. If you are using a local cache, and most machines do. Have you tried flushing it? On your router?

Have you tried using the treacert command to see if the domain is routing to your new or old host?

What about disabling IPv6? I have seen all sorts of oddities with that as providers try and get with the program, often with remarkable failures.

Then there is the issue of what appears to be a firewall or VPN port. 2080 is not a standard port for email. I have seen it used in intranets as a gateway port for web traffic (HTTP/HTTPS) generally so everything is sent through a proxy to filter content, sometime an edge apliance for malware detection. But far more commonly the port is 8080.

When I was googling the issue I noticed some mob called hostpapa used the port for synchronizing contact and calendars. https://www.hostpapa.com/knowledgebase/synchronise-calendars-contacts-cpanel/ so perhaps part of the issue is not email.

Does your new host even redirect port 2080, or just drop it as the firewall? Most hosts would have the port closed at the firewall I would guess as the recognized use of the port is by Autodesk Network Licence Manager (NLM). Not some thing everyone is using.

BTW This would be a whole lot simpler working with real domain names.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
For anyone reading this and wanting more info: In Thunderbrd

  • Menu icon > Settings > Composition
  • Scroll to 'Addressing' sub section
  • Select checkbox: 'Automatically add outgoing email addresses to my:'
  • Choose: 'Collected Addresses' from drop down options.

Please note: This will only collect the outgoing email addresses of contacts that are not in any other address book.

gregrogers9999 - what address book did you select for the outgoing email addresses?

Regarding some issues with Windows 11. If this is a new computer with Windows 11 installed then I suggest you acquaint yourself with a new feature called 'Smart app control'.

  • https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/topic/what-is-smart-app-control-285ea03d-fa88-4d56-882e-6698afdb7003

Access 'Firewall' It may be the default supplied by Windows or it be controlled by your Anti-Virus program.

  • Exit Thunderbird if it running.
  • Access Firewall
  • Make sure Thunderbird program is set up as an Allowed program.

Firefox: This is not really the correct forum but some basics you could check out. You can make sure Firefox is not running by using 'Task Manager'

  • Right click on bottom Task bar and select 'Task Manager'
  • Select 'Firefox' and click on 'End Task'

Then make sure Firefox is set up as the default browser. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/make-firefox-your-default-browser Access Firewall and make sure Firefox is set up as an allowed program.

There have been issue in changing from 32 to 64 bit and back again. As long as you are using the same versions of both, you can force the use of the old profile if the update changes it.
